text: Beginners question, probably more Python related than bflw, as things stand I generally run scripts as they are to do what I want, and any processes that I need as "daemons" are running in loops, or via cron, now I've moved over to the streaming API I'd like to understand how I can have the streams running and then access the data from external other scripts (I currently have them running via a supervisord process which is a loop that connects to the stream and writes all of the market books to MySQL) I then query the MySQL database in my other Python scripts, I'd like to miss out that step if possible and just query the stream directly from my other python scripts, anyone have any pointers?

elements.text: Beginners question, probably more Python related than bflw, as things stand I generally run scripts as they are to do what I want, and any processes that I need as "daemons" are running in loops, or via cron, now I've moved over to the streaming API I'd like to understand how I can have the streams running and then access the data from external other scripts (I currently have them running via a supervisord process which is a loop that connects to the stream and writes all of the market books to MySQL) I then query the MySQL database in my other Python scripts, I'd like to miss out that step if possible and just query the stream directly from my other python scripts, anyone have any pointers?

text:
<@UFPEU7URG> Others are far more sophisticated than me, but one thing I'd say, is that for streaming I very quickly found a MySQL database impossibly slow to connect to for streaming purposes, so I would consider another option if you need to refer to external data sources (e.g. json, csv or Reddit as example).

In terms of accessing other scripts, with BFLW using multiple threads I think is probably the approach you need, but it may be worth considering Flumine as that has 'worker' threads built in by design which appear to be what you might need.

elements.text:
Others are far more sophisticated than me, but one thing I'd say, is that for streaming I very quickly found a MySQL database impossibly slow to connect to for streaming purposes, so I would consider another option if you need to refer to external data sources (e.g. json, csv or Reddit as example).

In terms of accessing other scripts, with BFLW using multiple threads I think is probably the approach you need, but it may be worth considering Flumine as that has 'worker' threads built in by design which appear to be what you might need.

text: Streaming is super lightweight so just create a new stream per process, I don’t agree with the design of having a single stream that all your process use (unless you are running at a large scale.. <@UBS7QANF3> I think you disagree with me)

elements.text: Streaming is super lightweight so just create a new stream per process, I don’t agree with the design of having a single stream that all your process use (unless you are running at a large scale..
I think you disagree with me)

text: The issue with monitoring too many markets with one thread is that the decision process has to be very efficient to be able to process all updates. So it all depends what you try to do with every price update

elements.text: The issue with monitoring too many markets with one thread is that the decision process has to be very efficient to be able to process all updates. So it all depends what you try to do with every price update

text: Also depends if you recheck markets on a timer as well - often there are things to do if the price is stable

elements.text: Also depends if you recheck markets on a timer as well - often there are things to do if the price is stable

text: I use Redis pubsub

elements.text: I use Redis pubsub

text: Yeah I use a streaming timeout / snap (built into flumine) to give a constant update

elements.text: Yeah I use a streaming timeout / snap (built into flumine) to give a constant update

text: Thanks all, some ideas to consider there

elements.text: Thanks all, some ideas to consider there

text: Scaling becomes super easy when you broadcast stuff internally via pubsub IMO, even if you aren't running a huge operation it makes things super convenient for very little effort. I implemented mine with zmq which is more primitive than Redis but still totally sufficient. Plus you can make sure _all_ your clients are seeing the same data so it makes reconciling things easier

elements.text: Scaling becomes super easy when you broadcast stuff internally via pubsub IMO, even if you aren't running a huge operation it makes things super convenient for very little effort. I implemented mine with zmq which is more primitive than Redis but still totally sufficient. Plus you can make sure
all
your clients are seeing the same data so it makes reconciling things easier

text: Suppose I place a BACK limit order on a greyhound, with persistence type MARKET_ON_CLOSE. Suppose there is a non-runner. Is there a possiblilty that my back bet gets cancelled?

user_profile.real_name: Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon
user_profile.name: fcmisc

elements.text: Suppose I place a BACK limit order on a greyhound, with persistence type MARKET_ON_CLOSE. Suppose there is a non-runner. Is there a possiblilty that my back bet gets cancelled?

text: Not 100% sure on this, but I believe it CAN be cancelled. I know that if you place a MOC lay bet and it gets partially matched pre-closure, the remainder has to be >£10 liability, otherwise it gets cancelled.

elements.text: Not 100% sure on this, but I believe it CAN be cancelled. I know that if you place a MOC lay bet and it gets partially matched pre-closure, the remainder has to be >£10 liability, otherwise it gets cancelled.

text: Thanks for the suggestion, but it had more liability than £10. I recall reading something about Non Runners, but can't find it in the rules.
